title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno (Product Manager, Cloud Networking at Google) explains how AI-aware networking—centered on the GKE Inference Gateway and AI-specific load balancing—uses inference metrics and routing features to optimize GPU utilization and reduce latency. The approach adds prefix/body-based routing, cache-aware routing, LoRA awareness and network-level service extensions to insert API management and AI guardrails that sanitize prompts before they consume model compute.
bullets: Traditional networking/round-robin load balancing misses GPU saturation and inference-specific signals, causing latency and inefficient replicas selection.
GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing use metrics like KV cache utilization and queue depth to stack-rank least-loaded replicas.
Prefix caching and shadow copies of caches let the gateway reuse prefill computations to reduce GPU work and cold starts.
Body-based routing and LoRA-adapter awareness enable routing to the correct model/adapter instance without complex dev workflows.
Service Extensions insert API management and AI guardrails at the network edge to sanitize requests/responses and avoid wasted GPU costs.
takeaways: Monitoring and scheduling should include accelerator- and inference-specific metrics (KV cache, queue depth) not just CPU to avoid over/under-provisioning of GPU power.
Network-level caching and smart routing can reduce cold-starts and smoothing demand spikes, lowering peak power draw and start-up energy in data centers.
Edge guardrails that block invalid or policy-violating prompts before they reach models save GPU cycles, cutting compute costs and energy consumption.
Adopting AI-aware networking requires integration with orchestration (GKE) and low-latency network fabric—plan for increased intra-rack/network bandwidth and faster routing capabilities.
Higher GPU saturation improves cost-efficiency but raises power density per rack; reassess cooling, UPS, and power distribution sizing when deploying at scale.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this is a short showcase of the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with NVIDIA's DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation and RTX On. The clip is credited to @DigitalDreamsyt and was published by NVIDIA GeForce.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet
Showcased with DLSS 4 and Multi Frame Generation
RTX On (NVIDIA ray-tracing enabled) noted in the promo
Video credited to @DigitalDreamsyt
Published by NVIDIA GeForce on 2026-01-14
takeaways: If adopting similar RTX/DLSS 4-enabled workloads, expect demand for high-performance GPUs—plan power and cooling capacity accordingly.

If DLSS 4's Multi Frame Generation reduces per-frame compute (as intended for upscaling/efficiency), that could affect GPU fleet sizing and energy-per-frame metrics—validate with benchmarks before resizing infrastructure.
Procurement teams should consider availability of suitable datacenter/server GPUs and the upstream supply chain for critical minerals when forecasting capacity increases.
For game-streaming or GPU-accelerated rendering services, size UPS/backup and renewable integration for peak GPU load periods and ensure monitoring captures GPU power draw and thermal behavior.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, GE Vernova's video stresses the importance of anticipating an aging steam turbine rotor’s remaining life and planning the appropriate next steps to preserve steam-plant reliability. The description points viewers to a GE Vernova rotor end-of-life (EOL) resource and frames rotor life assessment as a core activity for dependable operations.
bullets: Focus: anticipate remaining life of steam turbine rotors to maintain plant reliability.
Action: assess rotor end-of-life and determine repair, overhaul, or replacement options.
Resource: GE Vernova provides a dedicated rotor EOL information page linked in the description.
Context: positions rotor lifecycle work as central to reliable steam-plant operations.
Publisher: video from GE Vernova, which emphasizes electrification and decarbonization.
takeaways: Prioritize rotor EOL assessments in asset-management plans to reduce unexpected outages and preserve reliability.
Schedule inspections and life-evaluation studies well before projected EOL to allow time for repairs or replacements without disrupting service.
Coordinate with OEMs or specialist vendors (e.g., GE Vernova) early to secure parts, refurbishment slots, and engineering support.
Factor rotor lifecycle timing into contingency planning for grid or data-center power availability to avoid capacity shortfalls.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG podcast episode discusses how the luxury goods market is shifting toward experiences, personalization and “affordable luxury,” while ESG and responsible sourcing (e.g., eco‑leathers, certifications) gain importance. The hosts note global trends like “luxury fatigue,” concentration of spend among the wealthiest, Poland’s growing but fragmented luxury market, and look ahead to AI, craftsmanship and human-centered experiences.
bullets: Global trends: luxury fatigue, top 2% of customers drive ~40% of spend.
Demand shift from ownership to experiences and personalization, with Gen Z preferring experiences over possessions.
ESG/responsible luxury rising—eco‑leathers, certifications and brand sustainability matter.
Poland: market still growing domestically, fragmented; luxury tourism, hotels and art market expanding.
Future drivers highlighted: AI-enabled services alongside continued emphasis on craftsmanship and human touch.
takeaways: AI uptake in luxury experiences and services implies rising compute and cooling needs—plan for increased data center capacity, resiliency and power density.
Growth in luxury hotels, spas and premium tourism can create localized peak loads and reliability requirements—consider onsite generation, storage and backup power solutions.
ESG and certification priorities mean luxury operators will seek low‑carbon and certified power sources—opportunities for renewable PPAs, onsite renewables and green certification alignment.
Personalization and immersive experiences will push edge computing and IoT deployments—anticipate distributed power and network requirements, plus lifecycle impacts on electronics supply chains.
Poland’s expanding but fragmented market suggests targeted infrastructure investments and flexible capacity solutions to serve concentrated luxury hubs (hotels, resorts, art venues).

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short video highlights that PJM Interconnection has prioritized reliability since 1927 and outlines how the organization works to make sure electricity is available when needed. It is positioned as an overview of PJM’s ongoing focus on keeping power reliable for customers.
bullets: PJM has made reliability its top priority since 1927.
The video explains how PJM works to ensure electricity is there when needed.
Positions PJM as a long-standing steward of electricity reliability.
Serves as an informational overview about PJM’s reliability efforts.
takeaways: For grid planners and substations: review PJM’s reliability materials to align local plans with regional expectations.
For data center operators: use PJM resources to better understand regional electricity availability and contingency considerations.
For renewables and storage project teams: learning PJM’s reliability approach can inform integration and operational planning.
For procurement and operations: consider PJM guidance when assessing risk and resilience for critical power loads.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames power systems' need to balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. Hitachi Energy positions digital‑centered power grid technologies as a way to improve stability, reduce downtime, and optimize performance across system levels.
bullets: Power systems must balance reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity for the energy transition.
Hitachi Energy emphasizes digital‑at‑the‑core grid technologies.
Goals include improving system stability, reducing downtime, and optimizing performance at every level.
Focus is on enabling capacity growth to support decarbonization efforts.
takeaways: Prioritize digital platforms that improve stability and minimize downtime to protect critical loads and reduce operational risk.
When planning capacity expansion, explicitly weigh reliability, flexibility and efficiency tradeoffs to support renewables and storage integration.
Evaluate suppliers that offer system‑level digital solutions to optimize performance across substations, transmission assets and grid operations.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video emphasizes that resilient industries rely on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. Hitachi Energy highlights working with customers and partners to build smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Resilience rests on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration.
Hitachi Energy collaborates with customers and partners to develop smarter systems.
Primary goals are improved productivity, reliability, and sustainability.
Focus applies across operations rather than a single asset class.
Call to action points viewers to further information via a link.
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency and process-optimization projects to strengthen resilience and reduce operating cost exposure.
Integrate digital monitoring and control tools to drive reliability and operational insights for grids and data centers.
Seek collaborative vendor or partner relationships to co-develop tailored ‘smarter systems’ rather than one-off purchases.
Balance investments to advance productivity, reliability, and sustainability objectives across assets (including substations, data center power, and storage).
